title: Reset identity values
sql:
-- Identity column values can clash with 
  -- values you insert manually =>
  -- duplicate key errors!
  -- Avoid this by setting the identitys nextval
  -- to the max in the column + 1
  create table t (
    c1 int 
      generated by default as identity
      primary key
  );

  insert into t values ( 1 ), ( 99 );

  insert into t values ( default );
  ORA-00001: unique constraint (CHRIS.SYS_C0015324) 
    violated on table CHRIS.T columns (C1)
  ORA-03301: (ORA-00001 details) row with column 
    values (C1:1) already exists

  alter table t modify c1 
    generated by default as identity ( 
      start with limit value 
    );

  insert into t values ( default );

  select * from t;

          C1
  ----------
           1
          99
         100

explanations.text:
The identity starts at one, 
but this value is already in the table
=> This raises a duplicate value exception

This sets the next value for the identity sequence
To one higher than the max value in the column
=> Next time it will insert 100
